dimensions.label: Element Type
dimensions.description: The type of the visual element.

cards.title: Mark
cards.description: A mark is a graphical element that represents a data point. The visual properties of the mark map to data. A mark can also indirectly support data encodings when it functions as a unit within a collection and the data mapping occurs at the collection level.

cards.title: Collection
cards.description: A meaningful grouping of marks or collections that encodes data.

cards.title: Annotation
cards.description: A non-encoding element that explicitly attaches to a target (mark, collection, guide, or other chart component) to explain, emphasize, or direct attention to it. It can take the form of a shape, highlight, or image.

cards.title: Guide
cards.description: A non-encoding element that supports interpretation of the scale of the encodings. It can be an axis, a legend, or an anchor element that provides reference by comparison.

cards.title: Decoration
cards.description: A non-encoding element that supports interpretation of the context of the dataset or the message of the visualization. It is neither an information nor a reference object and could be removed without affecting the interpretation of the representation and scale of the encodings. In contrast to an annotation, a decoration doesn’t attach to a target element.

cards.title: Scene
cards.description: A non-encoding element with the purpose of providing the “framing” for the other elements in the visualization. It often includes aspects of environment, background, point of view and lighting.

dimensions.label: Element Hierarchy
dimensions.description: The element’s structural level within the visualization’s composition, based on what it belongs to. Levels increase as you move from individual items to nested groups.

cards.title: Level 1
cards.description: Individual Marks (atomic items/links)

cards.title: Level 2
cards.description: A Collection of Level-1 items (first grouping)

cards.title: Level 3-5
cards.description: Nested groupings (Collection of Collections, etc.)

cards.title: No Hierarchy
cards.description: Element applies to the entire visualization (e.g., global background)

dimensions.label: Metaphorical Proximity to Data
dimensions.description: Degree to which the physically-inspired representation is semantically related to the associated data variables or theme. Indexical mappings are closest, symbolic are furthest, and iconic fall in between.

cards.title: Low Proximity (Symbolic)
cards.description: The visual element does not resemble the associated data/theme, the connection between them must be learned from conventions.

cards.title: Intermediate Proximity (Iconic)
cards.description: The visual element shares some similar qualities or resembles in an intuitive way the associated data/theme.

cards.title: High Proximity (Literal)
cards.description: The visual element is closely (physically/causally) connected to the data/theme.

dimensions.label: Metaphorical Proximity to Reality
dimensions.description: Degree to which the metaphor matches audiences’ real-world knowledge and experience. It corresponds to the level of familiarity with the mental image and perceptual affordances conveyed by the visual element.

cards.title: Low Proximity (Slightly Familiar)
cards.description: The visual element is only slightly familiar / feels more abstract or unfamiliar.

cards.title: Intermediate Proximity (Moderately Familiar)
cards.description: The visual element is moderately familiar.

cards.title: High Proximity (Very Familiar)
cards.description: The visual element is very familiar from everyday experience.

dimensions.label: Spatial Attributes
dimensions.description: Positional or geometric traits of an object.

cards.title: Position
cards.description: The object's location within the composition.

cards.title: Orientation
cards.description: The angular rotation or facing direction of an object.

cards.title: Size
cards.description: The size of an object, which can be in length, surface or volume.

dimensions.label: Geometry Attributes
dimensions.description: Attributes relating to the overall shape or surface details of a geometry.

cards.title: Shape
cards.description: The geometry's overall shape. It can be a recognizable shape (e.g. a star or a hand) or an abstract one.

cards.title: Surface
cards.description: Data is mapped to localized deformations on the object's surface, such as bumps, folds or extrusions.

dimensions.label: Material Attributes
dimensions.description: Attributes referring to the substance an object appears to be made of.

cards.title: Simple Materials
cards.description: Clearly separated materials applied to different areas or objects, often indicating distinct categories.

cards.title: Material Transformations
cards.description: From isolated material changes to complex changes that communicate physical processes.

dimensions.label: Structural Attributes
dimensions.description: Deformations or physical manipulations that affect an object’s form. Those deformations can be associated with the material state of an object. The change of form can arise from both implied external stimuli (e.g., a force deforming an object) or living mechanisms (e.g. the growth of a tree).

cards.title: Stretching
cards.description: Extension or elongation of an object's form.

cards.title: Twist
cards.description: Rotational deformation along an axis.

cards.title: Break / Shatter
cards.description: Fragmentation into separate pieces.

dimensions.label: Groups & Populations
dimensions.description: Patterns of repetition, accumulation, or dispersion of multiple objects.

cards.title: Count
cards.description: Focus is on the number of objects that make up the population.

cards.title: Density
cards.description: Focus is on how closely or widely the objects are distributed.

cards.title: Spatial Arrangement
cards.description: The spatial arrangement or topological patterns applied to objects inside the population.

cards.title: Lighting
cards.description: Light sources and illumination affecting the scene.

cards.title: Camera
cards.description: Point of view, angle, lens distortion.

cards.title: Environment
cards.description: Spatial and contextual elements surrounding a subject.

cards.title: Progression
cards.description: Sequential changes over time, showing stages or phases of development.

cards.title: Speed
cards.description: The rate of change or motion, representing velocity or pace.

cards.title: Rhythm
cards.description: Periodic or recurring patterns in time, creating temporal structure.

dimensions.label: Attribute Function
dimensions.description: The attribute function specifies the primary role a physical attribute plays in the visualization.

cards.title: Data-Encoding Attirbute
cards.description: The attribute’s value maps to a data variable. As a secondary purpose the attribute may also provide context in the same way as a contextual attribute does.

cards.title: Contextual Attribute
cards.description: The attribute does not map to data; its primary purpose is to provide context, theme, realism, or narrative tone. Functionally equivalent to Decoration, but embedded within another element.

cards.title: Static
cards.description: The physical attribute is static.

cards.title: Dynamic
cards.description: The physical attribute is dynamic.

dimensions.label: Semantic Congruence
dimensions.description: Degree to which an encoding’s perceived meaning directly conveys the encoded data variable. It is low when the mapping is immediately interpretable and high when it is arbitrary or requires substantial inference.

cards.title: Weak Congruence
cards.description: There is a weak semantic congruence between the data variable and the representation.

cards.title: Intermediate Congruence
cards.description: There is an intermediate semantic congruence between the data variable and the representation.

cards.title: Strong Congruence
cards.description: There is a strong semantic connection between the data variable and the representation.

dimensions.label: Biological Mechanisms
dimensions.description: The attribute appears to arise from living bodies or biological processes.

cards.title: Growth
cards.description: Structures that emerge, enlarge, branch, or differentiate over time.

cards.title: Decay
cards.description: Degradation caused by breakdown, death, or deterioration of living matter.

cards.title: Living Movement
cards.description: Movement caused by internal, biological processes.

cards.title: Respiration & Rhythms
cards.description: Periodic, life-like oscillations that convey internal cycles of living systems. Examples: “breathing”,  pulse/heartbeat dilations, tremor or “shaking”, bioluminescent pulsing.

cards.title: Infection
cards.description: Spread of living agents across an object or host. Examples: mold / mycelium, bacterial growth on a surface, moss / lichen.

cards.title: Self-Organization & Patterns
cards.description: Pattern formation or coordinated behavior arising from local interactions among many simple units, without centralized control. Examples: flocking / swarming, Turing patterns, phyllotaxis packing.

cards.title: Life-Cycle Events
cards.description: Biological stage transitions that change appearance, structure, or function. Examples: germination, metamorphosis, flowering / fruiting / seeding.

dimensions.label: Physics & Chemical Mechanisms
dimensions.description: The attribute appears to be produced by physics or chemical phenomena.

cards.title: Rigid-Body Mechanics
cards.description: Motion of bodies treated as undeformable solids under forces, constraints, and collisions.

cards.title: Deformable Solid Mechanics
cards.description: Shape changes and fracture of solids under stress, including elastic and plastic deformation.

cards.title: Fluids
cards.description: Phenomena related to liquid and gaseous flows, including diffusion and mixing phenomena.

cards.title: Burning & Smoke
cards.description: Oxidation-driven emission and transformation of matter producing flames or smoke.

cards.title: State Change
cards.description: Appearance and shape changes caused by heat transfer, temperature gradients, and transformations between phases.

cards.title: Force Fields & Particles
cards.description: Motion and structure shaped by force fields, which can be electromagnetic-based, wind or abstract ones. The gravitational field is not included in this category and is classified in “Statics & Dynamics”.

cards.title: Waves & Oscillations
cards.description: Repeating disturbances over time, either traveling through space (waves) or cycling in place (oscillations).

cards.title: Optics
cards.description: Effects arising from light–matter interaction and light transport.

cards.title: Weathering
cards.description: Long-term alteration of surfaces and structures by environmental exposure and mechanical/chemical processes.
